historicalFigures.name: Jose Rizal
historicalFigures.nativeName: José Protasio Rizal Mercado y Alonso Realonda
historicalFigures.background: Jose Rizal was a polymath, ophthalmologist, and writer who is considered the national hero of the Philippines. His novels exposed the abuses of Spanish colonial rule and inspired the Philippine Revolution.
keyDecisions: Advocating for peaceful reform rather than violent revolution (initially).
historicalFigures.legacy: Rizal is the father of Filipino nationalism. His death sparked the revolution that led to independence.
quotes: He who does not know how to look back at where he came from will never get to his destination.
The youth is the hope of our future.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Rizal Day is a national holiday. His image is on the currency. Every town has a Rizal monument.
modernInterpretations: Revered as a martyr and intellectual giant.
His pacifist stance is sometimes debated against Bonifacio's revolutionary approach.

historicalFigures.name: Andres Bonifacio
historicalFigures.background: Andres Bonifacio was the 'Father of the Philippine Revolution'. He founded the Katipunan, a secret society that sought independence from Spain through armed revolt.
keyDecisions: Initiating the Cry of Pugad Lawin (tearing of cedulas).
Leading the first battles of the revolution.
achievements: Mobilized the masses against colonial rule.
Unofficial first President of the Philippines.
challenges: Betrayal and execution by fellow revolutionaries.
historicalFigures.legacy: Bonifacio represents the courage of the common man. He is the symbol of armed resistance.
quotes: Love your country first, above all else.
What is death if it is for the sake of the country?
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Bonifacio Day is a national holiday. He is often depicted with a bolo knife.
modernInterpretations: Celebrated as a working-class hero.
His execution is seen as a tragedy of political infighting.

historicalFigures.name: Emilio Aguinaldo
historicalFigures.background: Emilio Aguinaldo was a revolutionary general and the first President of the Philippines. He led forces against Spain and later against the United States during the Philippine-American War.
keyDecisions: Ordering the execution of Andres Bonifacio (controversial).
Leading the war against the Americans.
historicalFigures.legacy: Aguinaldo is a complex figure. He established the first republic in Asia but his legacy is marred by the deaths of rivals.
quotes: We cannot free ourselves unless we move forward united in a single desire.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: June 12 is Independence Day. His home in Kawit is a national shrine.
modernInterpretations: Recognized for his role in independence.
Criticized for his handling of rivals and political compromises.

historicalFigures.name: Lapu-Lapu
historicalFigures.background: Lapu-Lapu was the Datu of Mactan who defeated Portuguese explorer Ferdinand Magellan at the Battle of Mactan in 1521. He is regarded as the first Filipino hero for resisting foreign colonization.
keyDecisions: Refusing to submit to Spanish authority.
Refusing to pay tribute to Magellan.
Leading his warriors in the Battle of Mactan.
achievements: First native to resist imperial Spanish colonization.
challenges: Facing a technologically superior enemy (armor, guns).
historicalFigures.legacy: Lapu-Lapu is the symbol of Filipino bravery and resistance. The Philippine National Police seal features him.
quotes: I bow to no king.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: A giant statue of him stands in Mactan. A fish is named after him.
modernInterpretations: Celebrated as the first defender of the archipelago.
A symbol of anti-colonialism.

historicalFigures.name: Manuel L. Quezon
historicalFigures.background: Manuel L. Quezon was the first President of the Commonwealth of the Philippines. He is known as the 'Father of the National Language' and advocated for social justice.
keyDecisions: Establishing Tagalog as the basis for the national language.
Lobbying for the Tydings-McDuffie Act (independence law).
Opening the Philippines to Jewish refugees during the Holocaust.
Establishing a government in exile during WWII.
achievements: Saved over 1,200 Jews from the Holocaust.
historicalFigures.legacy: Quezon is one of the most beloved presidents. Quezon City is named after him. His humanitarian act towards Jews is globally recognized.
quotes: I would rather have a government run like hell by Filipinos than a government run like heaven by Americans.
My loyalty to my party ends where my loyalty to my country begins.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: August is Buwan ng Wika (Language Month) in his honor. He is on the 20 peso bill.
modernInterpretations: Revered as a statesman and visionary.
His 'Open Door' policy is a source of national pride.

historicalFigures.name: Apolinario Mabini
historicalFigures.background: Apolinario Mabini was a revolutionary leader, educator, and lawyer who served as the first Prime Minister of the Philippines. Known as the 'Sublime Paralytic' and the 'Brains of the Revolution'.
keyDecisions: Advising Aguinaldo on the formation of the revolutionary government.
Refusing to take the oath of allegiance to the US (initially).
Advocating for the rule of law.
achievements: First Prime Minister and Foreign Minister.
challenges: Paralysis (polio) which limited his physical movement.
historicalFigures.legacy: Mabini represents the intellectual force behind the revolution. He proved that physical disability is not a hindrance to greatness.
quotes: Thou shalt cultivate the special gifts that God has granted thee.
Liberty is not license, it is liberty to do good and never to do evil.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is on the 10 peso coin. A symbol of intellect and integrity.
modernInterpretations: Revered as the conscience of the revolution.
His writings are studied for political philosophy.

historicalFigures.name: Gabriela Silang
historicalFigures.nativeName: María Josefa Gabriela Cariño de Silang
historicalFigures.background: Gabriela Silang was a revolutionary leader best known as the first female leader of a Filipino movement for independence from Spain. She took over the revolt of her husband, Diego Silang, after his assassination.
keyDecisions: Continuing the revolt after her husband's death.
Leading troops into battle on horseback.
Launching attacks on Spanish garrisons in Ilocos.
achievements: Led a guerrilla war for months.
historicalFigures.legacy: Gabriela Silang is a feminist icon. She proved women could lead in war. The women's organization GABRIELA is named after her.
quotes: We will fight until the end.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Statues of her riding a horse are common. A symbol of courage.
modernInterpretations: Celebrated as a pioneer for women's rights and independence.
Her bravery is legendary.

historicalFigures.name: Melchora Aquino
historicalFigures.background: Melchora Aquino, known as Tandang Sora (Elder Sora), was the 'Grand Woman of the Revolution'. Despite her old age, she provided shelter, food, and medicine to Katipuneros.
keyDecisions: Refusing to reveal the location of the Katipunan.
achievements: Survived exile and returned to the Philippines.
challenges: Old age (she was 84 when the revolution started).
historicalFigures.legacy: Tandang Sora is the mother figure of the nation. She represents the contribution of civilians to the war effort.
quotes: I have no regrets.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: A district in Quezon City is named after her. She is a symbol of hospitality and patriotism.
modernInterpretations: Revered for her nurturing role.
Proof that age is not a barrier to service.

historicalFigures.name: Juan Luna
historicalFigures.nativeName: Juan Luna de San Pedro y Novicio Ancheta
historicalFigures.background: Juan Luna was a Filipino painter, sculptor, and political activist of the Philippine Revolution. His painting 'Spoliarium' won the gold medal at the 1884 Madrid Exposition of Fine Arts.
keyDecisions: Joining the propaganda movement in Europe.
Working diplomatically for the revolutionary government.
Using art to highlight colonial oppression.
achievements: Put Philippine art on the world map.
Proved Filipino intellectual equality with colonizers.
challenges: Personal turmoil (killing his wife and mother-in-law).
historicalFigures.legacy: Luna is the greatest Filipino painter. The Spoliarium is a national treasure. His life was brilliant but tragic.
quotes: Genius has no country.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: The Spoliarium is the centerpiece of the National Museum. He is a source of artistic pride.
modernInterpretations: Celebrated as an artistic genius.
His crime of passion is a dark chapter often discussed.

historicalFigures.name: Antonio Luna
historicalFigures.nativeName: Antonio Luna de San Pedro y Novicio Ancheta
historicalFigures.background: Antonio Luna was a pharmacist and a general who fought in the Philippine-American War. He was regarded as the most brilliant general of the Philippine Republic. He founded the first military academy.
challenges: Conflict with other generals and Aguinaldo.
historicalFigures.legacy: Luna is the tragic hero of the war. His assassination is one of the great 'what ifs' of history. He demanded discipline and professionalism.
quotes: Cowards! Assassins!
The Philippines is worth dying for.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Subject of the hit movie 'Heneral Luna'. A symbol of strict discipline and patriotism.
modernInterpretations: Revered as a brilliant but hot-tempered leader.
His death is seen as a major reason for the republic's fall.

historicalFigures.name: Corazon Aquino
historicalFigures.background: Corazon 'Cory' Aquino was the 11th President of the Philippines and the first woman to hold that office. She led the 1986 People Power Revolution that toppled the dictatorship of Ferdinand Marcos.
challenges: The assassination of her husband, Benigno Aquino Jr.
historicalFigures.legacy: Cory is the symbol of democracy in Asia. The color yellow is associated with her movement.
quotes: I have no formula for ousting a dictator or building democracy. All I can suggest is to forget about yourself and just think of your people.
Reconciliation should be accompanied by justice.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Her death in 2009 sparked a massive outpouring of grief. She is on the 500 peso bill.
modernInterpretations: Revered as a saint of democracy.
Her administration is sometimes criticized for its handling of agrarian reform.

historicalFigures.name: Benigno Aquino Jr.
historicalFigures.background: Benigno 'Ninoy' Aquino Jr. was a senator and the leading opposition figure against the rule of Ferdinand Marcos. His assassination at the Manila International Airport ignited the People Power Revolution.
keyDecisions: Opposing the declaration of Martial Law.
Returning to the Philippines despite death threats.
achievements: Youngest mayor, governor, and senator (at the time).
historicalFigures.legacy: Ninoy is the modern hero of the Philippines. 'The Filipino is worth dying for' is his defining quote.
quotes: The Filipino is worth dying for.
I will never be able to forgive myself if I will have to live with the knowledge that I could have done something and I did not do anything.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Ninoy Aquino International Airport (NAIA) is named after him. He is on the 500 peso bill.
modernInterpretations: Celebrated as a hero who woke up the nation.
His death is the turning point in modern Filipino history.

historicalFigures.name: Ramon Magsaysay
historicalFigures.background: Ramon Magsaysay was the 7th President of the Philippines. He is known as the 'Champion of the Masses' for his populist policies and for defeating the Hukbalahap rebellion.
keyDecisions: Opening Malacañang Palace to the people.
Defeating the communist Huk rebellion through reform.
Wearing the Barong Tagalog (making it popular).
achievements: Ramon Magsaysay Award (Asian Nobel Prize) established in his honor.
challenges: His death in a plane crash.
historicalFigures.legacy: Magsaysay is the standard for good governance. He was loved by the common people.
quotes: Those who have less in life should have more in law.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is the most popular president in history. His death was a national tragedy.
modernInterpretations: Revered as the ideal president.
His populist style is often emulated.

historicalFigures.name: Carlos P. Romulo
historicalFigures.background: Carlos P. Romulo was a diplomat, soldier, journalist, and author. He was a co-founder of the Boy Scouts of the Philippines and served as the President of the UN General Assembly.
keyDecisions: Serving as aide-de-camp to Douglas MacArthur.
Serving as President of the UN General Assembly.
achievements: First Asian President of the UN General Assembly.
challenges: Representing a small nation on the global stage.
historicalFigures.legacy: Romulo is the quintessential Filipino diplomat. He gave the Philippines a voice in the world.
quotes: I am a Filipino.
It is the duty of the little Davids here to fling the pebbles of truth between the eyes of the blustering Goliaths.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His essay 'I am a Filipino' is a staple in schools. He is a symbol of Filipino intellect.
primarySources: I Saw the Fall of the Philippines.
modernInterpretations: Respected for his diplomatic skill.
His association with the Marcos regime is a point of criticism.

historicalFigures.name: Miriam Defensor Santiago
historicalFigures.background: Miriam Defensor Santiago was a senator, judge, and legal scholar. She was known as the 'Iron Lady of Asia' for her fearless crusade against corruption. She was the first Filipino elected as a judge of the International Criminal Court.
keyDecisions: Fighting corruption in the immigration bureau.
Voting against the opening of the Corona impeachment envelope.
achievements: Most authored laws in the Senate.
challenges: Health issues (chronic fatigue syndrome, lung cancer).
Being misunderstood for her fiery temper.
historicalFigures.legacy: Miriam is the best president the Philippines never had. She inspired the youth to be politically active.
quotes: I eat death threats for breakfast.
Stupidity is not a disability. Park elsewhere.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: She is a pop culture icon. Her 'hugot' lines and witticisms are legendary.
modernInterpretations: Revered as a brilliant legal mind.
Idolized by the youth.

historicalFigures.name: Fernando Poe Jr.
historicalFigures.background: Fernando Poe Jr., known as FPJ or 'Da King', was the King of Philippine Movies. He was a cultural icon who often played the role of the underdog championing the poor. He ran for president in 2004.
keyDecisions: Producing and directing his own films.
challenges: Citizenship issues raised during the election.
historicalFigures.legacy: FPJ is the hero of the masses. His movies are part of the Filipino psyche.
quotes: Huwag mong sabihing malakas ka! (Don't say you are strong!)
Isang bala ka lang! (You are just one bullet!)
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His movies are constantly replayed. He is a symbol of justice for the poor.
modernInterpretations: Revered as a cultural hero.
His daughter, Grace Poe, is a prominent senator.

historicalFigures.name: Efren Peñaflorida
historicalFigures.background: Efren Peñaflorida is a teacher and social worker who was named CNN Hero of the Year in 2009. He started the 'Kariton Klasrum' (Pushcart Classroom) to bring education to street children.
challenges: Growing up in a slum near a garbage dump.
historicalFigures.legacy: Efren proved that an ordinary person can make a global difference. He is a modern-day hero.
quotes: You are the change that you dream, as I am the change that I dream.
Each of us has a hero within us.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He inspired volunteerism among the youth. The pushcart classroom is a symbol of hope.
modernInterpretations: Celebrated as a role model.
His work highlights the power of education.

historicalFigures.name: Manny Pacquiao
historicalFigures.background: Manny Pacquiao is a professional boxer and politician. He is the only eight-division world champion in the history of boxing. He served as a senator and ran for president.
keyDecisions: Turning professional at a young age.
Moving to the US to train with Freddie Roach.
historicalFigures.legacy: Pacquiao is the 'Pambansang Kamao' (National Fist). He united the country during his fights (crime dropped to zero).
quotes: Life is meant to be a challenge, because challenges make you grow.
I fight for my country.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is the most famous Filipino in the world. A source of immense national pride.
modernInterpretations: Revered as a sports legend.
His political career is viewed with mixed opinions.
